title: Importing data into R
text:
Importing data into R

R can import a large range of data formats,
but you typically need to install a particular package for a particular file format.
RStudio provides convenient support for importing data.

title: Importing data into R
text:
Importing data into R

Complete now the lab_import_data exercises available on Github
If you don’t have R and RStudio running locally, you can use the following Binder link instead:
Note however that your progress will not be saved if you use Binder!

title: Importing data into R
text:
Dataframes

Dataframes are likely the most important data structure in R.
They are basically like a spreadsheet.
There are a few fundamental operations that you must know how to perform on data frames.

title: Importing data into R
text:
Main operations on data.frames

Inspect the size and type of a data.frame
See the content of a data.frame
Select a column of a data.frame
Filter rows of a data.frame
Modify or create new columns (mutate)
Save a data.frame (e.g., as a csv file)

(In all the examples I will use a data.frame called USArrests. You can learn more about this in-build dataset by typing ?USArrests)

title: Importing data into R
text:
Example dataset
In all the examples below I will use the Employee satisfaction and Salary (ESS) dataset, downloaded from Zenodo.

title: Introduction to Programming in R
text:
Key concepts

values / data (i.e., the content, e.g., "hello")
variables (data containers, e.g., x <- 5)
loops (e.g., “repeat operation 1000 times”)
control flow (e.g., “if x then y else z”)
functions (i.e., encapsulate transformations)

title: Introduction to Programming in R
text:
This is similar to Math!

f(x): 2*x + 1
f(5)
z = 3; f(z)
g(x): x if x > 0, else 0

title: Introduction to Programming in R
text:
Touchtyping for coders
Coding (i.e., writing code) requires using characters you might not be used to typing. Take a couple of minutes to figure out how to type the following characters on your keyboard:




( ) [] { } round, square and curly brackets
” ’ double and single quote
- _ hyphen and underscore
< > smaller and greater than
| pipe



` back tick
\ / backward and forward slash
$ dollar sign
~ tilde
# pound
& and operator

title: Introduction to Programming in R
text:

It is worth learning to touch type!
There are many free online resources:

https://www.typingclub.com/
https://www.keybr.com/
https://monkeytype.com/
https://www.speedcoder.net/
https://typing.io/

title: Introduction to Programming in R

Data structures


dimensions
homogenous
heterogenous




1
atomic vector
list


2
matrix
data frame


n
array

title: Introduction to Programming in R
section: Exercise: what data structures are these?

title: Introduction to Programming in R
text:
Variables / containers
We can store values (and functions and other stuff) in labeled containers called variables!
Example:
x <- 5
This is read as:

“x gets 5”
“we assign the value 5 to variable x”

Note: most programming languages use “=” instead.

title: Introduction to Programming in R
text:
Variables / containers
We can store more complex data structures:
my_vector <- c(1,3,5,7)
as well as transformations (more on this later):
my_function <- function(x){2*x+1}

title: Introduction to Programming in R
text:
How to name variables?
Requirements

must start with a letter or a period (followed by letter)
reserved words (e.g., TRUE, if, function) are forbidden
can’t contain spaces (e.g., my variable vs my_variable)

Recommendations

only use lower case letters, digits and underscore
use meaningful names
clarity beats brevity

title: Introduction to Programming in R
text:
Functions: Example 1
Calculate the mean of the following values:

age <- c(23, 26, 37, 45, 63, NA, 52)

Note: - getting help - argument, parameters - different functions expect different types of input - function outputs
Functions: Example 2
calculate the correlation between age and weight

age <- c(23, 26, 37, 45, 63, NA, 52)
weight <- c(70, 64, 80, 63, 92, 102, 77)

title: Introduction to Programming in R
text:
Create your own functions
To create your own functions use the following template:

my_function_name <- function(input_1, input_2) {
  
  # --- write your code here --
  # example:
  output <- input_1 + input_2
  
  # return the output
  output
  
}

text:

Write a function that computes the body mass index (in an R script!)
\[ bmi = \frac{weight}{height²} \]
\(weight\) in kg and \(height\) in m

Are there other terms you have heard before that are not listed here?

title: Introduction to R
text:
base R
When you install R, it comes with a set of core functionality.
This core functionality is sometimes referred to as base R (even though there are other packages included by defaul, e.g., stats, datasets)
Note that across successive updates of R (i.e., “versions”), that core functionality changes; usually quite slowly and in a “back-compatible way”–a main goal is stability.
Examples:
Base R includes for example functions to compute the mean and standar deviation of a vector of numbers.

title: Introduction to R
text:
packages (for R)
Base R is limited and highly controlled.
You can however extend the cababilities of R by

using code written by others

code snippets shared by others
packages that you can download and install

write your own code

Examples:

ggplot2
dplyr
tidyverse

title: Introduction to R
text:
base R + packages
This is a powerful and widely used pattern:

have the core be very stable and reliable
encourage creativity and diversity

title: Introduction to R
text:
How to install packages?
Its super easy to install and use packages!
Step 1: download the package on your computer

install.packages("package_name")

Step 2: load the package when you needed (so you can use it)r

library("package_name")


We will see and do this many times during this course.

title: Introduction to R
text:
R & RStudio

R is a programming language
R is a piece of software that understands the R language
RStudio is a separate piece of software that makes it easier and nicer to user R;
RStudio is one of many IDE that you can use for coding

title: Introduction to R
text:
Top 10 reasons to use R

elegantly designed for modern data science (tidyverse)
highly effective in integrating the full data science workflow (e.g., quarto)
comprehensive, state-of-the-art methods (e.g., packages)
exceptional data visualization tools (i.e., ggplot2)
free and open
runs on Linux, Mac, and Window
active development
strong community
great resources
great value on the job market

title: Introduction to R
text:
The tidyverse
This is a collection of well-designed packages that work well together.
If you learn how to use it, you will likely never go back to anything else.

https://www.tidyverse.org

Course Introduction

title: Course Overview
text:
This is the homepage for MAPEA-85: Introduction to R taught by Prof. Pedro Cardoso-Leite at the University of Luxembourg within the Master in Psychology–Evaluation and Assessment program.
All course materials will be posted on this site.

title: Course Overview
text:
What?
This course is an introduction to programming in R. Programming is an essential skill that is at the heart of modern technologies, including generative AI systems like ChatGPT. In today’s digital age, understanding the core principles of programming is not just an academic pursuit; it’s an essential skill that empowers you to navigate and act in the modern world. As a student of psychology, acquiring programming skills will greatly benefit you, be it for analyzing data for research or practice, for developing new digital products like websites, or for better understanding and using software developed by others.
In this course we will focus on R–a powerful, open-source programming language that excels in statistical computing and graphics. It’s widely used in academia and industry for its flexibility and rich ecosystem of packages tailored for data analysis, visualization, and modeling. By learning R, you’ll equip yourself with tools to handle complex datasets, perform robust analyses, and present your findings compellingly. While our focus is on R, the programming concepts that you will learn are common to most programming languages.
This course is very much hands-on: the “lecture” part aims to be minimal and offer instead many guided activities for “learning-by-doing”. By the end of this course, students should be familiar with the main programming concepts (e.g., variables, for loops) and they should be able to write simple R programs. Most importantly, we hope this course will empower students to confidently embark on their programming journey.

Add your syllabus content here.

title: Chapter 2: Introduction to R
text:
In this chapter we will cover some key elements that compose the R universe. We will see what programming means, what R is and how it relates to related terms like packages, Rstudio and the tidyverse that you may have heard of before.
We will discuss why doing data analysis using code is a good idea. We will also highlight some of the key features that make R particularly interesting for data analysis.

text:
In this chapter we will explore different ways of importing tabular data into R.
We will go over several examples and troubleshoot some common issues when importing data.
We will also introduce “data frames”, the R equivalent of a spreadsheet and various ways to inspect them.

Students are often not well prepared to integrate all the steps of this loop. They lack practical skills to implement the data analysis and reporting efficiently and in a way that can be reproduced.

https://r4ds.hadley.nz/

Freedom and empowerment

You are restricted when using “tools” developed by others;
If you learn to create your own “tools”, the possibilities become endless.
You will gain in efficiency and freedom (you can delegate work to computers).
You will better understand the digital world.

Code is text
age <- c(18, 23, 43)
mean_age <- mean(age)
print(paste0("The mean age is ", round(mean_age, 1), " years."))

Install RStudio!

text:
IDE: Integrated development environments
The R GUI is bare bones.
Programmers use IDEs to work effectively.
IDEs provide tons of features that make programming easier and more fun.

text:
RStudio

https://docs.posit.co/ide/user/ide/guide/ui/images/rstudio-panes-labeled.jpeg

title: Getting started using R
text:
Some key benefits of RStudio

see and work on more files at the same time
see the current state of your environment
inspect data
code completion, syntax highlighting
help
package management
data import wizzard
…and much more.

title: Getting started using R
text:
Install packages
Packages offer you additional functionality (functions, code, data not included in base R).
You will almost always use additional packages, but depending on your specific needs you might use different ones.

title: Getting started using R
section: To use a package involves two simple steps:
text:
To use a package involves two simple steps:
Step 1: download the package
This is done only once (but you may need to redownload if there is a newer version of package).
To download a package, you need to “install” the package (e.g., using install.packages("package_name"))
Step 2: load the package
A package is not automatically available; you need to activate it before you can use it.
To activate a package, first you must have installed it. Second you need to call library("package_name").
 Beginners often mix this up this two steps.
You can do those steps either using code (e.g., typed in the console) or by using RStudio package panel.

title: Getting started using R
text:
Example: installing the “swirl” package (using code)
Step 1:
In the console type
install.packages("swirl")
“swirl” is the name of the package we want to download on our computer.
This command will download the code from that package from CRAN and put in on your computer.

title: Getting started using R
text:
Example: installing the “swirl” package (using code)
Step 2:
Each time you want to use that package, you need to load it into R.
In the console, type:
library("swirl")
Now the code from the swirl package is aviable for use.

title: Getting started using R
text:
Tidyvserse
Tidyverse is a set of well-designed packaged that work very well together to effectively accomplish 90% of the data science tasks.

title: Getting started using R
text:
Conclusion
We’ve installed R and RStudio and we’ve seen how to install packages.
We are now ready to start programming.
